Title: 5 questions for Rep. John Moolenaar
Content:
ByANTHONY ADRAGNA

06/13/2025 04:00 PM EDT

Presented by

With help from Aaron Mak

Rep. John Moolenaar (R-Mich) | House handout

Hello, and welcome to this week’s installment of the Future in Five Questions. This week we interviewed Rep. John Moolenaar, the chair of the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party. That post puts the Michigan Republican at the center of some of the thorniest geopolitical issues, including winning the technological arms race with China.

Moolenaar talks to us about artificial intelligence and his ideas for an “America First AI Policy” that would keep the U.S. ahead, block China from accessing U.S. technology and expand international partnerships with appropriate guardrails.An edited and condensed version of the conversation follows:

What’s one underrated big idea in tech?

AI can be used as a weapon. From helping cyber criminals to building autonomous systems to injecting Chinese Communist Party propaganda directly to the U.S. public, AI has immense power — and we need to treat it that way.

And that starts with securing the chips that power it. And I co-sponsoredThe Chip Security Act, which is a bipartisan bill that would require location tracking for advanced American chips and mandate reporting if they’re diverted or misused. Right now, American chips are being smuggled into China and used to train AI models that serve the CCP’s military and surveillance state. And we can’t allow that.

When you think about it, in the Cold War we tracked nuclear material, and today we should be tracking advanced chips, because they’re just as strategically important.

That is a simple idea, but it could determine whether American innovation is used to protect freedom or to power authoritarian control.

What’s a technology that you think is overhyped?

I think the idea that high-end compute is the only path to AI is overhyped, and the Chinese model DeepSeek proves it. Even though there are restrictions on advanced chips, the CCP found a workaround, and they built an AI system that censors, surveils and pushes propaganda using stolen AI models and likely smuggled chips.

Our committee detailed all of thisin our DeepSeek report, and what it shows is that the CCP is adapting fast, and they’re not just chasing high-end hardware — they’re trying to indigenize the entire tech stack: [Graphics processing units], cloud computing and the tools to manufacture chips themselves.

So we need to think better, not just about cutting off chip exports, but about securing the entire ecosystem. The race is not just about who has the most powerful hardware, but it’s about who controls the platform and protects the values built into it.

What could the government be doing regarding technology that it isn’t?

We need to treat AI like the strategic asset it is, not just another tech trend. And I joined alongside ranking member [Rep. Raja] Krishnamoorthi (D-Ill.) in a bipartisan letter urging the Commerce Department to act — and act fast.

We need clear standards for AI safety and transparency before these models are deployed, especially in critical sectors like defense, infrastructure and finance.

That means safety testing, transparency requirements for new models and strong oversight of training data, so we don’t end up with CCP-style systems like DeepSeek, which are hardwired for propaganda and control.

We also need to build more capacity at home: More fabs, more data centers and more secure supply chains, and close the export loopholes. The CCP is trying to indigenize the full tech stack. If we don’t control the whole program, we’re giving them the tools to bypass our restrictions.

With our values, we need to lead globally — and our allies need to adopt similar guardrails — so that we can prevent Beijing from their techno-authoritarianism. We still have the edge, but if we want to keep it, we have to act like we intend to win.

What book most shaped your conception of the future?

Recently, I read “The Peacemaker” by William Inboden, and it shaped how I think about American leadership in the dangerous world that we have today.

It was about Ronald Reagan and about how he faced Soviet aggression, nuclear brinksmanship and economic instability, but he stood firm with moral clarity, military strength and a deep belief in America and our values.

It didn’t happen overnight. When you think of the Soviets launching Sputnik, America didn’t back down. We stepped up and invested in science, defense and education. And that wave of innovation allowed Reagan’s strategy to dominate technologically — and our strong military defense — but we also won the war of ideas.

That’s the advantage that free societies grounded in faith and truth have over these authoritarian regimes. I believe the future is going to be shaped by those who lead in AI, semiconductors and quantum, but even more so by those who defend the values beneath them. And Reagan showed how to lead with strength and with faith and we need to work with other like-minded nations to work together to defeat this authoritarianism — and some of these partnerships that are emerging with China, Russia, North Korea and Iran.

What has surprised you the most this year?

What has shocked me the most when it comes to the work we’re doing with our select committee is how much of our American-made technology — our investor dollars and even our taxpayer dollars — are benefiting the Chinese military and surveillance state, and despite our sanctions, our export controls and national security warnings, the CCP is still building AI-enabled weapons using our chips, our money, our cloud services, even our research.

We need to get much more serious about our enforcement, and that’s precisely why we need an America irst AI policy to ensure America always retains a majority of global compute and leads the free world in this effort.

The White House’s plan to extract more investmentsfromsemiconductor manufacturers might actually be working — though the strategy may have its limits.

On Thursday, chip fabricator Micron said it wouldinvest an additional $30 billionto expand its Virginia plant, and construct a new facility in Idaho. This comes as President Donald Trump’s Department of Commerce renegotiates manufacturing grants that the Biden administration had agreed to furnish under the 2022 CHIPS Act. Micron received $6 billion in CHIPS funding last year, and will now get an additional $275 million, as well as a “white glove” service to loosen and expedite permitting.

In May, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the administration would demand that companies ramp up their investments if they wanted to receive the CHIPs grants they’d been promised. Trump has also claimed he’s been able induce extra investments by threatening companies with tariffs in renegotiations: He said in April that he raised the prospect of imposing100 percent tariffson the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, leading it to pitch in another $100 billion. (TSMC declined to comment on Trump’s version of events whenDFD asked earlier this week. Micron said it could not comment on whether tariffs were part of its renegotiations due to it being the quiet period before reporting quarterly results.)

As Trump notches wins in his pressure campaign, Chris Miller, the Tufts University historian who wrote the widely influential book “Chip War,”told DFD earlier this weekthat aggressive tactics can only take the White House so far. “Companies are not going to do more than is economically rational,” he said. “That will be a limiting factor in terms of what kinds of renegotiations we end up seeing.”

It seems like Trump hasn’t hit that limit quite yet.

The Los Angeles protests are reigniting the argument aboutmisinformation during moments of tumult, especially since AI may be making the problem worse.

As with other recent upheavals, like the George Floyd protests or Jan. 6, 2021, riot, misleading photos and videos taken out of context are circulating online — Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas)reposted a clipof a burning car that was actually from 2020. AI is now complicating the situation even further. For example, a fakeAI-generated videoof a National Guardsman talking about “gassing” protestors gained hundreds of thousands of views this week.

POLITICO’s California Decoded teamreported on Fridaythat at least three Democratic state lawmakers are monitoring the situation, which they say emphasizes the need for AI legislation. “The AI-generated images are inflaming the situation,” state Sen. Josh Becker told Decoded, who added that theCalifornia AI Transparency Actwill eventually be sufficient to counteract such deepfakes. The law requires watermarks to signal that a certain piece of media was AI-generated. The act was passed last year, but won’t go into effect until January.

However, the First Amendment has stifled AI content laws in the past. A federal judge in October blocked California fromenforcing a banon deceptive AI content. While watermarks may seem less extreme than a ban, they may stillraise free speech issues.

Title: China’s next big AI plan
Content:
ByAARON MAK

11/05/2025 04:43 PM EST

Presented by

With help from Alfred Ng

Chinese President Xi Jinping wants to establish a global AI standards body.  | Adek Berry/AFP via Getty Images

When Chinese President Xi Jinping visited South Koreathis week, the centerpiece of his trip wasn’t some multibillion-dollar “Art of the Deal” transaction he’d brokered. Rather, it was his proposal to establish a global organization to set AI standards.

In the vacuum left by President Donald Trump — who flew home from South Korea before the conference officially started — Xi pitched a Shanghai-based group that would set rules for international AI governance. As my colleagues at POLITICO’sMorning Techreported, this would allow China — rather than America or Europe — to mold how the world approaches AI.

These aren’t just idle prospects. In fact, China now has a significant track record of shaping global tech policy, and by extension the global economy, by influencing theobscure international bodiesthat institute standards for the tech sector. While not as flashy as mega semiconductor deals, these organizations sketch out the blueprints for how technology is designed and used around the world, from 5G to satellites.

As we enter the AI age, China is now clearly laying the groundwork to shape the AI ecosystem with those international standards. What would that mean for the rest of the world?

A message from Meta:

Meta is investing $600 billion in American infrastructure and jobs, creating opportunities in communities across the country.

Phil, a Lead Building Engineer in Los Lunas, New Mexico, has seen the impact that Meta’s investment can bring.

“Supporting my family used to mean leaving my hometown and missing out on special moments,” he says. “Now, it doesn’t.”

Explore Phil’s story.

Its long-game strategy to wieldinstitutional power has already given China a lot of sway in debates over critical rules. The country has previously installed leaders at theInternational Telecommunication Unionto favor Chinese technologies and minimize security concerns with Huawei and ZTE. China has also been trying to get support from groups like the Internet Engineering Task Force, which sets technical standards for the Web, to adopt new online protocols that would make it easier to enable surveillance and censorship.

By shaping more and more standards in telecom, the internet and other sectors, China can quietly create a built-in advantage for its domestic companies.

“You’re talking about whose standards will be applied,” said Brett Schaefer, a former member of the UN’s Committee on Contributions. “If it’s a Chinese company, those will become the basis for working practices moving forward. It gives you a huge economic advantage.”

This is one of the wonkier, less-appreciated— but very important — subplots of China’s global rise.

It began after the 2008 housing crisis, according to Luke Hogg, director of tech and telecom policy at the Foundation for American Innovation. The U.S. government and Silicon Valley cut back on travel budgets for sending delegates to the conferences where these bodies discuss policy, and also hosted fewer of those conferences due to the expense. “The U.S. started to pull back [...] and the Chinese saw this as an opportunity to exert more influence in a lot of these places,” Hogg told DFD.

Over the last decade, China has formally integrated such efforts into its big-picture policy plans, like the Belt and Road Initiative, a global infrastructure project.

As fewer Americans attend these standards meetings, China has been increasing its delegations. The country has also given subsidies to domestic tech companies to encourage them to send more representatives. Its government makes an effort to staff some of these groups as well, especially at the United Nations.

“They’ve invested time and money to make sure that the Chinese place a lot of interns into UN bodies, and frequently those interns subsequently are hired as UN employees,” said Mark Lambert, who worked on the State Department’s Asia policy in the Biden and first Trump administrations. “They’ve done this very well, in a way that other members of the security council have not.”

The Chinese Communist Party is also effective at coordinating with domestic tech industries to boost its influence globally, sending company representatives to certain international meetings and official representatives to others. “They’ve been very creative,” Hogg told DFD.

Xi’s proposal to create an entirely newinternational AI body would give the country even more leverage over tech standards, if it can steer how the institution is set up.

There’s currently no singular, widely accepted AI standards organization to, for example, determine how exactly the technology can collect data. So the CCP can be the first mover.

The U.S., for its part, is aware of China’s strategy and officially says it wants to renew its involvement in the international standards community. Trump’sAI Action Planincludes a section on countering “Chinese Influence in International Governance Bodies,” which tasks the State and Commerce Departments with finding ways to leverage U.S. power through standards setting.

The White House did not reply to DFD’s inquiry about its efforts by deadline. But Office of Science and Technology Policy director Michael Kratsios has been attending international meetings to promote sector-specific AI standards, rather than an overarching body. Sens. Marsha Blackburn and Mark Warner havealso introduced legislationto coordinate and fund U.S. participation in related meetings.

Hogg praised the initiative, but noted that “there is also a bit of muscle memory that’s been lost since the 2010s, so it’s not like we’ve seen an immediate phase shift in U.S. engagement in these bodies — it’ll be a long process.”

A message from Meta:

Former Federal Trade Commission chairand long-time tech industry adversary Lina Khan is back in politics, co-chairingNew York City Mayor-elect Zohran Mamdani’s transitionteam — POLITICO’s Alfred Ng reports.

So-called “Silicon Alley” residents may be relieved to hear that Khan doesn’t plan to continue her anti-monopoly crusade against Big Tech. Instead, a Khan spokesperson told DFD, her focus will be on identifying personnel and policy recommendations for Mamdani’s progressive economic agenda.

“Honored to serve as co-chair of the transition as we work to build an administration that governs effectively and delivers a city where all New Yorkers can build a good life,” Khansaid in an X poston Wednesday.

The Department of Energy is investing $625 millionto bolster quantum research at its national labs.

The 2018 National Quantum Initiative Act initially established the centers to speed up research that could lead to breakthroughs in quantum science, and industry groups have been pushing Congressto reauthorizeit. As POLITICO’sKelsey Tamborrino reports, the DOE funding will help five labs improve superconducting materials, refine algorithms and chip components, scale quantum devices and enable large-scale quantum computers.

DOE undersecretary for science Darío Gil said in a statement, “The renewal of DOE’s National Quantum Information Science Research Centers will empower America to secure our advantage in pioneering the next generation of scientific and engineering advancements needed for this technology.”

Screenshot/X

Title: This California Republican thinks he has an in with China policy
Content:
ByTYLER KATZENBERGERandCHASE DIFELICIANTONIO

03/10/2025 03:05 PM EDT

Available free through April 11, POLITICO Pro’s Technology:California Decoded newsletter will explore how the Golden State is defining tech policy within its borders and beyond.

A bill from Assemblymember Carl DeMaio would require businesses to obtain consent from California-based users before sharing or storing their data in foreign countries.  | Pool photo by Rich Pedroncelli

— A California Republican seeks common ground on Chinese tech fears.

— San Jose’s mayor floats running city programs like startups, tying pay to performance.

Welcome to California Decoded!Happy Monday, hope you remembered to spring forward yesterday. Send feedback, tips and story ideas to[email protected]and[email protected].

FIRST IN DECODED:CHINA IN THE CROSSHAIRS —One of the California Legislature’s most outspoken conservatives is looking to crack down on businesses sharing personal information overseas amid national concern over China’s access to American data.

New legislation from Republican AssemblymemberCarl DeMaio, first shared with California Decoded, would require businesses to obtain consent from California-based users before sharing or storing their data in foreign countries.

DeMaio said his legislation is aimed squarely at China — and it comes as Congress and PresidentDonald Trumpare grappling with how to address bipartisan fears that the Chinese Communist Party is weaponizing data held by TikTok and other China-based platforms to spy on Americans. (TikTokhas refuted claims it shares data with CCP officials.)

“This is a national security threat,” DeMaio told Decoded in an exclusive interview. “Their tech companies are heavily dominated and controlled by the Chinese government.”

China hawkism is set to dominate the tech conversation in Washington this week. Trump yesterdaysaid there are four potential buyersinterested in purchasing TikTok’s U.S. operations after Congress forced the company to divest its American holdings or face a nationwide ban. And on Tuesday, the Office of the U.S. Trade Representativewill hold an investigative hearingon China’s quest for dominance in the semiconductor industry.

But whether that talk will spur further action in Congress to protect Americans’ data from Chinese-owned companies is yet to be seen. Republicansalready have their hands fulltrying to unite their razor-thin House majority behind a budget resolution, meaning second-order issues like data privacy are stuck on the backburner.

“Even if something should be easy in Congress, it never is, and that’s particularly true on privacy and AI legislation,”Jon Leibowitz, former chair of the Federal Trade Commission under the Obama administration, told Decoded.

And even if Congress advances a bill clamping down on overseas data sharing, there’s no guarantee Trump will sign it. The president hasbacktracked on the TikTok ban— despite kickstarting the idea during his first term — after conservative creators and Trump’s campaign used the platform to reach young voters during the 2024 election.

DeMaio said California needs to step up to fill the void with Washington in gridlock.

“California is the biggest player in technology,” he told us. “If we adopt this standard, it really does then have a cascade effect that would probably create a national standard.”

Whether DeMaio’s bill can pass in deep-blue California is also an open question, even though it targets a bipartisan issue. DeMaio has a reputation asan outspoken conservativein the Democratic-controlled Legislature, which could make his colleagues on the other side of the aisle skeptical of working with him.

Plus, his bill could attract opposition from Big Tech-aligned groups, even as the industry has aggressively courted conservatives following Trump’s reelection. Tech industry groups often argue that California businesses already maintain strict data privacy standards and that additional regulations would be unnecessary and costly.

DeMaio, anticipating pushback, said that “all good ideas will generate opposition.”

But he was confident that the issue would draw bipartisan support, even if any bill that ultimately lands on Gov.Gavin Newsom’s desk doesn’t have his name on it.

“I don’t care if someone takes a good idea and makes it happen. That’s all that matters to me. I don’t need the credit,” he said. “If my bill spurs that conversation, great.”

NOW— Trump meets with the Technology CEO Council at the White House.

INTERVIEW:TECHING UP THE PLACE —The mayor of the self-declared “Capital of Silicon Valley” wants the city to run more like — surprise — a startup. San Jose MayorMatt Mahantold California Decoded he plans to propose tying the pay of senior staff to improvements in areas like homelessness, an idea inspired by his time working at tech companies in the valley.

“I think this will be shocking to many people inside city hall,” Mahan said, outlining his idea before a public announcement as part of his annual budget proposal Tuesday.

Mahan spent the first half of his term wrangling with the San Jose City Council over what the city’s main priorities should be. Now he wants to take the techie tack of going all in on solutions and swiftly changing course when he’s not getting results.

Before becoming mayor, he ran small companies focused on voter engagement and fundraising and said he wants to model his approach on the ethos of the nimble startup.

The mayor said he’s expecting “quite a bit of discussion and debate” when the particulars are hashed out with the city council.

Translation:This could be a primetime political skirmish to watch in the Bay Area’s biggest city.

San Jose City CouncilmemberPamela Campostold Decoded she was wary of putting too much focus on just the numbers when it came to improving city services.

“What we don’t want is a system where leaders are competing for credit or prioritizing metrics over solutions,” Campos said. Asked if she supported the proposal, Campos said: “Overreliance on quantitative targets is going to prioritize short-term fixes over long term solutions,” adding, “We need more time to explore something like this.”

But a potentially bristling board is just the first hurdle.If the plan gets the rubber stamp, it would still have to be approved by voters next year.

Mahan said it’s the kind of change he campaigned on bringing to city hall, and that it would apply to department heads and other senior staff — himself included. He said getting the city totrack dataon issues like community safety and cleanliness was the first step.

Now comes the politically fraught portionof the show where the mayor will have to go up against the council to hash out what exactly a reasonable decrease in homelessness might be that warrants a pay bump, for example.

“I think we are now at a point after my two years in which we should be able to set targets, set actual goals, around our biggest priorities like ending unsheltered homelessness, and have a feedback loop which is so missing in the public sector,” Mahan said.

IMITATION GAME —Chip giantNvidia announced another partnership, this time with the state of Utah, to create AI skills programs in community colleges and universities.California announced a similar partnershipwith the Santa Clara company last year.

— State Attorney GeneralRob Bontasays his office shut down 42 fraudulent cryptocurrency websites that scammed people out of at least $6.5 million in 2024 (AG office)

—Michael Bernick, the former director of the state Employment Development Department, says the tech industry’s pandemic-era hiring sprees were “never sustainable” (Mercury News)

— Technical problems during the California Bar exam offer a cautionary tale (Crunchbase News)

— AfterSam Bankman-Friedtried to indirectly appeal to Trump for a pardon in an unauthorized interview withTucker Carlson, he was placed in solitary confinement (The New York Times)

Compiled by Nicole Norman

Have a tip, event or Silicon Valley gossip to share? Do reach out:Emma Anderson, California tech editor;Chase DiFeliciantonio, AI and automation reporter; andTyler Katzenberger, Sacramento tech reporter.

Title: No tariff reprieve for the tech world
Content:
ByARI HAWKINS

04/14/2025 10:00 AM EDT

President Donald Trump gestures while speaking during an executive order signing event in the Oval Office of the White House on March 31, 2025 in Washington, D.C.  | Andrew Harnik/Getty Images

— President Donald Trump plans to instruct his Commerce Department to launch a Section 232 investigationthat could lead to new tariffs on semiconductors and related technologies.

— U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said trade deals could be reached within the next few weeks,even as some countries cast doubt on Trump’s 90-day timeline.

— United Kingdom Prime Minister Keir Starmer suspended tariffs on 89 productsas the country pursues a new trade deal with the United States.

It’s Monday, April 14. Welcome to Morning Trade.Got news tips? Suggestions? Want to grab a coffee?Hit us up at:[email protected],[email protected]and[email protected]. Follow us on X:@_AriHawkins,@drdesrochersand@tradereporter.

TECH ON THEIR TOES:The White House will soon task Commerce to conduct an investigation that could lead to new tariffs on semiconductors and potentially more electronics,your host reported on Sunday,in a move poised to fuel anxiety for the world’s largest technology companies.

One step back:The investigation will be launched under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, which allows the president to restrict imports deemed a threat to national security. The move would also lay the groundwork for greater friction with chip hubs in East Asia, such as Taiwan.

A White House official told your host the purpose of the probe is to “revive U.S. manufacturing in critical technologies” — and that Commerce plans to offer industry a public comment period. A final timeline for the investigation and an official start date has not been set.

What it means for industry:The update puts a damper on celebration from the technology industry after guidancepublished by the U.S. Customs and Border Protectionshowed that some chips as well as smartphones, computers and more electronics were excluded from the president’s so-called reciprocal tariffs.

The exemption was viewed as a win for tech companieslike Apple and Nvidia, which were facing potential price hikes amid manufacturing costs that would skyrocket under Trump’s tariff plans.

But Trump rejects that framing:“There was no Tariff ‘exception’ announced on Friday. These products are subject to the existing 20% Fentanyl Tariffs, and they are just moving to a different Tariff ‘bucket,’”Trump wrote on his social media platform Truth Social on Sunday.

“We are taking a look at Semiconductors and the WHOLE ELECTRONICS SUPPLY CHAIN in the upcoming National Security Tariff Investigations,” Trump wrote.

The expected chip probe is a thorn in the sideof not only the technology sector, but also a longer list of critical industries that rely on foreign inputs and had hoped the new guidance was a signal the president might provide a wider range of exemptions.

“Ever-changing trade policies are a recipe for mass confusion and declining optimism in the stability of the U.S. market,” Adam Thierer, senior fellow for the Technology & Innovation team at the free-market think tank R Street Institute, told Morning Trade.

But he added that doesn’t mean tech companies will all come out to immediately condemn the expected investigation, or bash Trump’s tariffs publicly. “A lot of people in the tech community are still holding their tongues a bit and hoping for a return to normalcy,” Thierer said.

Don’t be too surprised:Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick on Sunday downplayed the guidance and suggested new tariffs would hit electronicswithin two months.

"[Trump is] saying they’re exempt from the reciprocal tariffs, but they’re included in the semiconductor tariffs which are coming in probably a month or two,” Lutnick said on ABC’s “This Week” on Sunday.

USTR weighs in:Meanwhile, USTR Jamieson Greer reiterated the need for new tariffs on semiconductors and downstream products onSunday in an interview on CBS’s “Face the Nation,”and suggested new sectoral tariffs would be coming soon.

“It’s not really an exception. That’s not even the right word for it,” Greer said of the posted guidance. “What happened is, this type of supply chain moved from the tariff regime for the global tariff, the reciprocal tariff, and it moved to the national security tariff regime, where we have studies ongoing for pharmaceuticals, for semiconductors, metals, et cetera.”

PREPARE FOR DEAL-MAKING:Greer in the interview floated that trade deals with select partners could be coming together in the short term, saying “I think we’re going to be there with several countries in the next few weeks.”

State of play:The White House is in serious talks on reciprocal tariffs with only a select number of countries — Vietnam, India, South Korea and Japan — prioritizing existing trading partners that are strategic to countering China.

Despite the upbeat assessment from Greer,the White House’s approach has left most countries in the dark about how to permanently stave off Trump’s tariffs.

Even some nations actively engaged in negotiations have expressed confusion about the administration’s priorities and have cast doubt on whether a 90-day timeline is realistic, at which point Trump’s planned reciprocal tariffs are scheduled to snap back into force.

“We really don’t know what the Trump administration wants,” said one diplomat from an Asian country, who is close to the negotiations.

POLITICO has more on how countries are reacting to Trump’s trade talks here.

UK’S OFFERING:United Kingdom Prime Minister Keir Starmer is suspending tariffs on 89 products as part of a wider effort to protect British firms from Trump’s tariffs,POLITICO Europe reports.The move is sure to please the American president and comes as both countriestout progress toward a trade agreementthat could stave off Trump’s tariffs.

Timeline:Thesuspension of tariffson a range of products from electric vehicle batteries to agave syrup extends until July 2027, the U.K. government said in a statement.

Reminder:The U.K. was slammed with 10 percent U.S. tariffs across the board on April 2, on top of 25 percent duties on aluminum, steel, vehicles and car parts.

BOB’S MESSAGE TO CANADA:Robert Lighthizer, former USTR during Trump’s first term, told a conference of Canadian conservatives in Ottawa that he is in favor of the renegotiation of the USMCA, but said Mexico should be excluded,POLITICO’s Mike Blanchfield reports.

RESOLUTION TO WITHDRAW FROM THE WTO:Rep.Tom Tiffany(R-Wis.)introduced a resolutionin the House last week to formally withdraw from the WTO, which he says has failed to uphold fair trade and undermined American farmers.

“It has been two decades since Congress last voted on whether to continue our membership in this deeply flawed organization,” Tiffany said. “The American people deserve to know if their elected officials stand with them, or with China’s allies in the WTO.”

— China ramps up US tariffs to 125 percent in new salvo against Trump,per POLITICO Europe.

— Democrats go all in on unproven insider trading allegations as they target Trump’s tariffs,POLITICO reports.

— White House trade aide Peter Navarro denies clash with Elon Musk over tariffs,POLITICO reports.

— Forget tariffs — Beijing is already choking off US exports on the sly,POLITICO reports.

— ‘I Think He Means It’: Scott Bessent’s Endgame,POLITICO reports.

— Democratic senators press USTR on long-term tariff strategy,per POLITICO Pro.

Title: ‘The president is obsessed’: Trump fixates on Xi call amid faltering trade talks
Content:
The White House says a call this week between the president and China’s leader is "likely" as it tries to restore a fragile truce in the U.S.-China trade war.

President Donald Trump thinks a call with China’s leader Xi Jinping will help reset souring trade talks. But even if that conversation happens this week, as the White House said is “likely,” it’s doubtful to be the breakthrough Trump is hoping for.

“The president is obsessed with having a call with Xi,” said one person familiar with the trade talks, convinced he can personally hash out deep-seated divisions between the world’s two largest economies mano a mano with Xi.

That conviction belies the difficult position the U.S. is in as it tries to pressure China to fundamentally reorder their nearly $600 billion trade relationship, without doing lasting political damage at home. And it renews questions about what Trump’s endgame is in a trade war with China that is increasingly turning into a game of chicken.

The person familiar with the trade talks, who was granted anonymity to speak candidly about their private conversations, said the administration is under “a lot of pressure” because of China’s block on critical minerals, crucial components for everything from auto and electronics manufacturing to munitions production. “I don’t think Xi is too interested in exporting any more rare earths or magnets to the United States, he’s made his position clear,” the person added, though they predicted there’s a “good likelihood” Xi would take the call to at least hear Trump out. “The president has some leverage, and the question is when he’s ready to impose maximum pressure on the Chinese government.”

A former Trump official close to the White House, granted anonymity to candidly discuss the president’s strategy, said: “Trump feels like a call between principles is a way to cut through a lot of this noise, and get right to the heart of the matter.”

Other outside observers remain skeptical Trump will actually be able to get Xi on the phone. Since the start of the president’s second term, White House officials have been publicly promising a call between the leaders is imminent. Trump even tried to suggest throughoblique comments in Aprilthat the two had spoken since Trump’s inauguration.

“Beijing has a sharp nose for weakness, and for all his bravado, Trump is signaling eagerness — even desperation — to cut a direct deal with Xi,” said Daniel Russel, who was assistant secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs in the Obama administration. “That only stiffens Beijing’s resolve.”

The Chinese government has also been shaken by Trump’s public spectacles in the Oval Office — including high-profile meetings with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and South African President Cyril Ramaphosa — which has made it wary of leader-level diplomacy.

“The PRC sees President Trump as unpredictable, which poses risks reputationally for President Xi,” said Rush Doshi, former National Security Council deputy senior director for China and Taiwan in the Biden administration. “It’s not usual practice for PRC diplomats to put the leader at risk of a potentially embarrassing or unpredictable encounter.”

White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters Monday that the leaders would “likely talk this week,” echoinga prediction National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett made Sunday. But a White House official, granted anonymity to discuss behind-the-scenes conversations, said a call has yet to be scheduled.

Asked about a potential call during a press briefing on Tuesday,China’s Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian replied, “I have no information to share on that.” The Chinese Embassy in Washington did not respond to a query about it. But a statement from China’s Commerce Ministry on Mondayaccusing the U.S. of “stirring up new economic and trade frictions” suggests they aren’t in a conciliatory mood.

It’s just part of the finger pointing that’s ensued since Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greerreached an agreementwith their Chinese counterparts in early May to lower tensions in a trade war that has threatened to capsize both economies. The deal brought U.S. tariffs on China down from a floor of 145 percent to 30 percent, while Beijing slashed levies on U.S. imports to 10 percent and promised to lift barriers on critical mineral exports. The deal gave both sides a 90-day deadline to launch a new dialogue on a broader trade deal to address U.S. grievances about Chinese trade practices.

But since then, miscommunication and conflicting expectations have ground new talks to a halt — before they even started. The Trump administration has accused the Chinese government of slow-walking its restart of shipments of critical minerals and rare earth magnets.

“When they agreed in Geneva to remove their tariff and their countermeasures, they removed the tariff like we did. But some of the countermeasures, they’ve slowed on,” Greer said on CNBC on Friday.

Automakers have started to warn thatimpending shortages of rare earth magnetscould force them to halt production and shutter factories in a matter of weeks. The magnets are critical to auto construction, from transmissions and fuel pumps to steering sensors and airbag actuators.

The two countries also remain stalled on the issue that ostensibly caused Trump to launch the trade war in the first place — fentanyl. China has offered two proposals to the White House, including one in February after Trump imposed his initial 10 percent tariff on China, Canada and Mexico.

“Everyone agrees that for any additional progress to happen on tariffs, the gateway is fentanyl,” said a business official, granted anonymity to discuss sensitive conversations.

But the U.S. has been unresponsive to the fentanyl offers, which were described as being intentionally designed by China to provoke a discussion about what Beijing could feasibly do to stem the flow of the precursors that Mexican cartels use to make the highly addictive drug.

Many Trump administration officials remain skeptical China will follow through with any agreement on fentanyl — underscoring the distrust some officials feel about the negotiations.

The Chinese government, for its part, has been angered by U.S. moves to limit U.S. exports for key Chinese industries, like semiconductors and aircraft, citing national security concerns.

Less than 24 hours after the Geneva announcement, the Commerce Department issued a warning to U.S. companies discouraging them from using chips made by the Chinese tele-computing giant Huawei, suggesting that using those chips would risk violating U.S. export control laws.

That caught Chinese officials by surprise, according to one business official granted anonymity to discuss sensitive conversations. “The Chinese side seems to legitimately believe that there was going to be this sort of 90-day stay of new actions, and that there might be some small things that happened, but nothing totally earth shattering,” said the official.

The U.S. has also angered China withnew moves targeting Chinese students studying in the U.S.

“The U.S. unilaterally keeps stirring up new economic and trade frictions, exacerbating the uncertainty and instability of bilateral economic and trade relations, and not only does it not reflect on itself, but also hits the other side with a backhanded accusation that the Chinese side violates the consensus, which is a serious deviation from the facts,” aChinese Commerce Ministry official said Monday.

Trump’s expectation that a call with Xi can reboot U.S.-China trade talks on those issues and render substantive results defies the diplomatic and policymaking protocols of China’s ruling Chinese Communist Party.

“Trump is a deal maker. Xi Jinping is not a deal maker — he’s a Party guy at the top of an administrative superstructure,” said Harry Broadman, a former assistant U.S. trade representative in the George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton administrations. “I cannot imagine that Xi would get into specifics — at most they might agree on certain principles but that’s not likely to satisfy Trump.”

There’s also a risk that a call between the two leaders could backfire for Trump by undermining longer term trade negotiations with China.

“Elevating talks to the leader level might remove the ability to put together the kind of deeper and bigger deal that ultimately requires more consideration and time, so jumping to the leader level can be risky,” said former NSC official Doshi.

But the former Trump official dismissed the idea that there are major downsides to pushing for a Trump-Xi conversation. “From the U.S. perspective, what’s the big downside to the call? You ask for it. If they don’t do it, it’s like, ‘well, you know, we’re trying, they’re not even trying,’” the former official said. “And if they do it, maybe we get some progress.”

Title: Congress pulls the rug on U.S. plan to beat Huawei
Content:
U.S. officials of both parties spent years struggling to develop homegrown alternatives to China’s telecom giants. The GOP abruptly defunded its biggest tool.

A global, six-year campaign to counter Chinese tech dominance took a hit this summer when Congress defunded a key research program to create a worldwide alternative to 5G giant Huawei.

In July’s One Big Beautiful Bill, Republicans cut the bulk of remaining grant money — nearly $1 billion — for the Wireless Innovation Fund, which was supposed to create a new, American-dominated type of 5G network.

The budget savings were used to pay for President Donald Trump’s tax cuts.

“To cut it came completely out of the blue,” said Sen.Mark Warner(D-Va.), vice chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee. “I think it’s crazy. It’s like a gift to China.”

The defunding is a major setback for America’s prolonged effort to root Chinese-made equipment out of the world’s telecommunications backbone. That campaign hasreached into the American heartland, causeddrama with alliesinternationally and even led to global intrigue when Huawei’s chief financial officer was arrested, extradited to the U.S., and later traded in a prisoner swap.

The program was launched to address the security risks created by the world’s dependence on Chinese telecom equipment. Worried about the dominance of Huawei and ZTE, Congress began paying to develop an alternative technology called an open radio access network, or open RAN.

The idea is still in the early stages, and although some companies have started to incorporate open RAN technology into their networks, it remains heavily supported by government money for research and deployment.

Warner, who secured the money in 2022with support from both Democrats and Republicans, believes the move this summer caught even some Trump administration officials off guard.

As recently as February, Trump talked up the technology in ameeting with Japan’s prime minister.

Many congressional Republicans, too, continue to support the idea. “We don’t want China to win,” Sen.John Cornyn(R-Texas), who unsuccessfully fought the cut, told POLITICO. “In the absence of U.S. developing alternatives like ORAN, I think there’s a risk that they will.”

The cut was spearheaded by Senate Commerce ChairTed Cruz, who framed the decision as fiscal responsibility.

The Texas Republican never commented publicly on the matter. In response to questions from POLITICO, his staff sent a list of talking points that the technology was flawed and not paying off as expected. A Cruz spokesperson declined to comment further for this report.

The crisis for open RAN demonstrates the challenges of using industrial policy to reshape an established marketplace — and to regain American footing in an area that it long since ceded ground.

The program was still relatively new, launched in 2023 with $1.5 billion in funding from the previous year’s bipartisan CHIPS and Science Act.

When Cruz first floated the idea of clawing back the grant money in June, it set off surprise and consternation in both parties, including from senior GOP colleagues like Cornyn. The idea never appeared in House Republicans’ budget plans. But on Capitol Hill, Cruz’s office defended his objections to the program in a one-pager shared at the time with POLITICO, criticizing the lack of anoverarching strategyfor the grants and questioning whether they were accomplishing their goals. The cut quickly became part of the final version of the reconciliation package.

In the wake of the funding cut, the Trump administration says it still supports the broader objectives that drove the $1.5 billion program, and is still sensitive to alleged risks from China’s dominance of 5G technology.

“Seeing what China has done globally with rare earth restrictions raises questions about communications and other critical infrastructure,” said a U.S. official, who requested anonymity to describe delicate issues. “Resilience and security can only be assured when we work with trusted vendors.”

The official declined to answer questions about why Trump signed the open RAN cut.

In a June statement to POLITICO, a State Department spokesperson reiterated its support for open RAN, and said its diplomats were pushing the case “that secure technology is the foundation of a prosperous economy.”

That contradictory approach to the issue extends to Capitol Hill as well. Just days after Trump signed the reconciliation law slashing the remaining $850 million in open RAN grants, the House of Representatives unanimouslypassed a billdirecting the government to alert small companies to the benefits of open RAN — even letting them know about how to participate in the program the GOP had just gutted.

Open RAN has plenty of critics, including Cruz, who point out that the technology has been slow to develop. While some telecom companies have begun incorporating aspects of open RAN, the technology hasn’t been seen as widely transformative as initially hoped.

Skeptics also fear the current rollout would furtherentrench the existing telecom giants,including traditional European hardware playerslike Ericssonand Nokia, the largest non-Chinese 5G equipment makers, which integrated open RAN into their own marketing and offerings.

Cruz’s team also questioned open RAN on technical grounds, arguing in the June document that its technical architecture actually increases security vulnerabilities, and that in “a time of rising geopolitical cyber threats, policymakers should not push unproven architectures as the foundation of critical infrastructure.”

House Energy and Commerce ChairBrett Guthrie(R-Ky.) was among the first evangelistspushing for grantsfive years ago, but recently told POLITICO the cutback now seems “reasonable.”

“We fought for the open RAN program as it was developing and coming into being,” Guthrie said. “Eventually these programs have to stand on their own, and they can’t be funded forever. … With open RAN, there’s a lot of startup money, a lot of it’s been initiated, and now it’s time for it to live on its own.”

It’s not clear if that’s a viable option yet. Some longtime U.S. champions of the technology, including thetelecom companies EchoStarandMavenir, ran into financial challenges.

Supporters of open RAN research say the money cut by Congress could have addressed the looming challenges it was facing.

While the wireless fund’s initial rounds centered on hardware and broad R&D, the next grants were supposed to be devoted to the software challenges of operating an open 5G network — “kind of the game-changer for open RAN,” said Diane Rinaldo, who served in the first Trump administration and now leads the Open RAN Policy Coalition, which includes AT&T, Cisco, Google and Nokia as members.

Future funding rounds may have also sought to directly drive commercial deployment. She lamented the lost opportunities.

“It was incredibly unfortunate and upsetting to us,” Rinaldo said. “But it was about the money, not about open RAN — that was kind of made loud and clear to us.”

The industry was eager for the money: This spring, the administration announcedmore than 90 applicationsrequesting nearly $3 billion from the planned next round of funding.

A spokesperson for the National Telecommunications and Information Administration, the Commerce agency administering the grants, said that research funding from the program’s first two rounds would continue, and that it’s still “exploring options” for pursuing the planned third funding round, without detailing specifics. (Accounting for the program’s full budget, there’s likely a small amount of funding left after the cut.)

Supporters are now on the hunt to take advantage of the administration’s other wireless research money, like R&D funding for 5G and 6G at the Pentagon, and to redouble efforts to convince U.S. officials of the technology’s global merits.

Its advocates acknowledge the speedbumps, but say getting the U.S. strategy on course may prove necessary to countering China.

“The truth is, ORAN has taken longer to implement than we’d hoped,” Warner told POLITICO. “But if we’re ever going to be competitive against Huawei, we have to move against the kind of traditional stack of equipment.”

Title: Inside the Chinese AI threat to security
Content:
ByPHELIM KINE

10/06/2025 04:34 PM EDT

Presented by

With help from Aaron Mak

Security experts are concerned with DeepSeek's data collection and China-aligned rhetoric. | Riccardo Milani/Hans Lucas/AFP via Getty Images

At the beating heartof the American artificial intelligence debate under President Donald Trump is anxiety about China, whose fast-moving AI capacities have raised fears of both economic dominance and security threats.

China’s rising tech power fueled the argument between Nvidia’s CEO and Washington’s national security world over the past week, after Jensen Huangaccused China hawksof being “unpatriotic” for wanting to limit the number of Chinese who come to the U.S. to study. That drew sustained blowback fromlawmakersand analystswho accused Huangof airbrushing reality.

Behind their concerns is Beijing’s policy of pouring billions of dollars into AI research, development, hardware and infrastructure in a bid to outgun Silicon Valley. The global AI competition with China drives Trump’sAI Action Plan, his microchip tariff policy, even much of his energy policy.

The economic fears are clear: It’s a powerful industry, and the country that wins the AI race will wield a technological edge that may grant it dominance in the 21st-century economy

The security threat from China, however, is more diffuse. When hawks wave the “national security” flag, they can be talking about issues ranging from military strategy to pop-culture propaganda.

“The Chinese have the highest quality AI of the actors we worry about,” said Kathleen Hicks, deputy defense secretary in the Biden administration. “At the strategic level, we’re less worried about Russian AI.”

So, when it comes to China, what’s the exact nature of the security threat? We asked four experts to break it down for us — and the answers run from the deeply wonky to the apocalyptic.

Cyberwar.In the simmering global battlefield of hacking, code-breaking and digital attacks, AI may supercharge Beijing’s alreadypotent cyberwarfare capabilities. Integrating AI into Chinesestate-linked cyberhacking operationssuch as Volt Typhoon and Salt Typhoon — which have already burrowed deeply into U.S. telecommunications and infrastructure networks — may enable them to become the ultimate killer app in future conflicts.

“AI is showing promise to accelerate, extend and automate different parts of cyber operations,” said Helen Toner, interim executive director of Georgetown’s Center for Security and Emerging Technology. “That might mean it’s able to disrupt the navigational abilities or impact critical infrastructure on the home territory of an opponent.”

Chatbot spies.Amid the domestic anxiety about chatbots, one lesser-appreciated risk is their potential as espionage machines. The overlap of China’smilitary industrial complex with domestic tech firmsmakes the user data that DeepSeek and other Chinese AI systems collect fair game for the People’s Liberation Army. That’s because China’sNational Intelligence Lawobligates Chinese companies to “support, assist and cooperate with national intelligence efforts.”

Chinese AI applications “extract data as they go, and that data can be combined with other information and used in all kinds of ways by the Chinese state because of their civil-military fusion,” Hicks said.

If more Americans use Chinese-made chatbots, Beijing could weaponize that data through tactics including bespoke disinformation campaigns designed to sow chaos among specific segments of the U.S. population. (Imagine social media campaigns designed around the personal anxieties of first responders, banking sector workers or military personnel.)

Chinese AI chatbots don’t yet have the reach of U.S. rivals such as ChatGPT or Gemini.But that may change in the face of growing demand for AI services, and China’s improving capacity to build cheap, efficient AI platforms.

Propaganda narratives.The 2024 law to ban TikTok was driven in part by worries that its Beijing-linked parent company could manipulate the algorithm to show American users the content that China wanted them to see.

With AI platforms, this is already happening. Research published last week by the nonprofit media freedom advocacy organization Reporters Without Borders revealed that China’s three most popular AI chatbots — DeepSeek; “Ernie,” which is produced by Chinese search engine company Baidu; and e-commerce giant Alibaba’s “Qwen” chatbot —produced responses to more than 100 queries on 30 topicsthat consistently aligned with Chinese government rhetoric.

That could deliver Beijing a propaganda win in developing countries where the ubiquity and lower cost of Chinese products allow Chinese AI to dominate.

The effect: “A lot of answers or interpretations of inputs based on Chinese training and worldviews,” said Harry Krejsa, former assistant national cyber director in the White House’s Office of the National Cyber Director during the Biden administration.

“Data poisoning.”U.S. military moves to integrate AI into warfighting systems raises the risk that stealth Chinese AI could corrupt those mechanisms with malicious code geared to a specific trigger.

“You could have some embedded [military] AI model that is providing almost concierge-like service that then recognizes at some point, ‘Hang on, we’re in a contingency over Taiwan? Let me start giving bad information or slightly adjusting the course of action that I’m proposing to be in China’s favor,’” said Toner.

Then there’s the even bigger contest for humanity’s future.Looming over all this is the question of whether China or the West will develop “superintelligence” first — and what that will mean for civilization itself.

“The race for AI leadership is really two races unfolding at once — once for AI commercialization and another for artificial superintelligence,” said Mark Beall, who directed AI strategy in the Pentagon in the first Trump administration. “A superintelligent system could, in theory, impact strategic stability and potentially rewrite the logic ofmutually assured destruction.”

An ASI piloted by the People’s Liberation Army could allow Beijing to neutralize the U.S. military’s strategic nuclear arsenal — its ultimate war deterrent — and allow China to pursue unchecked aggression across the Taiwan Strait and beyond.

With that comes thethreat of China’s ideology dominating the world— which has worried experts sinceeven before the current AI boom.

A former Pentagon insider outlinedher fears that artificial intelligence could escalate future conflicts into full-blown nuclear warfare, reportsPOLITICO’s Calder McHugh.

Mieke Eoyang, the Biden administration’s deputy assistant secretary of defense for cyber policy, told Calder in an interview that many popular large language models don’t have the guardrails necessary for use in the military context. She warned that autonomous weapons systems known as “killer robots” need guardrails that ensure their decisions aren’t skewed toward unnecessarily escalating conflicts.

“There are [...] concerns with the ‘swarms of killer robots’ people are worried about, which involve escalation management,” she told Calder. “How do you ensure that you’re not engaging in overkill? How do you ensure that the AI is responding in the way that you want?”

An AI system that is poorly calibrated for conflict escalation could have dire consequences for nuclear warfare. Publicly available AI models are often bullish on the use of nukes. “I think one of the challenges that you have with AI models, especially those that are trained on the past opus of humans, is that the tendency toward escalation is a human cognitive bias already,” Eoyang said. “It already happens without AI. So what you’re enabling with AI is for that to come through faster.”

The Paris public prosecutor’s officeopened an investigation into Apple over privacy concerns with its Siri voice assistant, POLITICO’sOcéane Herrero reports.

France’s cybercrime agency is leading the investigation, which comes after a former Apple subcontractor blew the whistle on Siri for collecting recordings of users to improve its responses. The whistleblower alleged the recordings could reveal intimate or confidential information, and identify users.

An Apple spokesperson told POLITICO, “Apple has never used Siri data to create marketing profiles, has never made it available for advertising and has never sold it to anyone for any reason whatsoever.”

Screenshot/X

Stay in touch with the whole team: Aaron Mak ([email protected]); Steve Heuser ([email protected]); Nate Robson ([email protected]); and Ruth Reader ([email protected]).

Title: China’s new military muscle
Content:
ByJOE GOULD

11/19/2025 05:30 AM EST

Updated11/19/2025 11:57 AM EST

With help from Phelim Kine

The Pentagon's annual China report will have fresh fodder. | Lintao Zhang/Getty Images

WELCOME TO GLOBAL SECURITY.We’re breaking down which of Beijing’s new weapons are troubling China watchers, the weak links in drone supply chains and Taiwan’s dependence on foreign energy.

Read more about our mission. We’ll publish daily for free during major industry events, and put our otherwise weekly newsletter behind the paywall for U.S. and EU Pro subscribers starting in 2026.

Read our coverage of the Halifax International Security Forum on Saturday and Sunday, after which the newsletter resumes Dec. 3.

Should the U.S. go ahead with F-35 fighter sales to Saudi Arabia?Email me at[email protected]with tips, pitches and feedback, and find me on X at@reporterjoe.

China spent the past year pairing cutting-edge battlefield technology with traditional military hardware — all at a pace that risks outstripping the U.S.

The Pentagon will zero in on this buildup in next month’sannual China military power report. The administration’s upcoming National Security Strategy and National Defense Strategy will offer an additional picture of America’s response.

Look ahead:The China report is expected to lay out how the People’s Liberation Army is projecting force, moving troops and equipment and operating in regions where the U.S. once assumed it held uncontested advantages. It also arrives amid intensifying questions about whether the Pentagon is keeping its focus on China as it shifts more attention and resourcestoward the Western Hemisphere.

China’s naval expansion includes newamphibious ships with landing decks for dronesand fielded a drone-specific carrier, enabling deployments far afield.

“If your plan was to try to be ready for a Taiwan invasion in 2027, this is the kind of stuff you do in 2025,” saidThomas Shugart, a former submarine warfare officer.

Drowning in drones:No area of China’s military modernization has accelerated more this year thanuncrewed systems. They include large, long-endurance drones, small expendable platforms and a fast-growing effort that mirrors the Pentagon’sdrone “wingman” programfor crewed jets.

The focus underscores Beijing’s embrace of tactics deployed on the battlefield in Ukraine, where low-cost tech stymied larger, more costly weapons systems that are the backbone of the U.S. military arsenal.

“The Russia-Ukraine war is offering extraordinary real-time lessons for what peer-to-peer conflict looks like in the 21st century,” saidAlexander Gray, former chief of staff of the National Security Council in the first Trump administration. “The lessons are sobering in regards to the People’s Republic of China’s modernization and priorities.”

The Pentagon’s ambitious tech and manufacturing ramp-up,recently outlined by U.S. Defense SecretaryPete Hegseth, is an effort to catch up to China.

China is “doubling down on its investments in drones,” saidBecca Wasser, an expert on the U.S. defense industry and strategy. “China’s industrialization and ability to tap into its manufacturing sector for defense needs is above none else at this point, and it’s part of why we see so much of an emphasis on the reindustrialization of America.”

Boat loads of trouble:Beijing’sgrowing navy— which at more than 200 warships is nowthe world’s largest— is boosting China’s strategic edge in regional power projection. Beijing is seemingly gambling that the size of its fleet can outmatch the U.S. Navy’slarger and more technologically advancedwarships.

“Just the sheer number of destroyers, frigate equivalents,future aircraft carriersand submarines makes China’s ship construction program pretty stunning,” said retired Vice Adm.Robert Murrett. “The quantity has a quality of itself, and the quantity that China is looking at is pretty noteworthy.”

The centerpiece of China’s naval buildup in 2025 has been a third aircraft carrier, the Fujian, which entered service earlier this month. The Fujian is two-thirds the size of the USS Gerald R. Ford carrier, but like the Ford, it boastsstate-of-the-art electromagnetic catapultsto launch its J-35 and J-15T fighter jets.

“China has made clear that it’s absolutely their intention by mid-century to have what they call a world-class military, and one of the markers of that is carriers,” Shugart said.

Beach barge menace:The PLA’s prep for a possible invasion of Taiwan — which Hegseth said could occuras soon as 2027— also advanced this year. A new military barge system, firstreported by Naval Newsin January, addresses the challenges of beach landings by creating a floating bridge for cargo ships to unload tanks or trucks directly onto the shore.

That eliminates the need for fixed port infrastructure, making the vessels “a logistics enabler for a potential Taiwan crisis,” saidLauren Dickey, former acting director for Taiwan policy at the Pentagon.

Beijing’s military investments are rapidly reversing the traditional calculus of U.S. superiority in a possible conflict with China.

“If you’d asked 10 or 15 years ago how it would go if the Chinese went after the U.S. or Taiwan, I’d have said they’d lose,” Shugart said. “Now I’d say if things keep going the way they’re going for another 10 or 15 more years, it would be pretty certain to go in the other direction.”

China’s grip on core components for military drones is turning into one of the biggest constraints on NATO’s ability to ramp up production for itself and Ukraine, according toa new assessment. The analysis, from the London-based Royal United Services Institute, found that motors, magnets, infrared sensors and battery cells remain overwhelmingly sourced from China in spite of Western efforts to diversify.

Chokepoints:RUSI maps three vital components that Beijing could choke off: rare-earth permanent magnets for electric motors; germanium used in thermal-imaging lenses and lithium-ion battery cells, where China’s output dwarfs every other producer. Even when the drones are assembled in Europe or the U.S., the report says, those components often flow through Chinese suppliers.

The author, RUSI researcherRobert Tollast, said that motors are the first barrier Western companies hit when trying to shift away from China. “Everyone mentions motors,” he said, noting that magnet vendors are facing pressure from their Chinese suppliers, who are asking more pointed questions about to whom their vendors are selling.

Infrared systems aren’t any safer. Tollast described germanium — the mineral used to make the lenses that go into night-vision and targeting cameras — as “the gold standard of infrared lens material.” Prices have spiked five times over the past two years, he said.

Another problem is the batteries to power many drones. China spent years building massive electric-vehicle cell factories, which now gives it control over the price and supply of the battery types used in many drones. Tollast said Chinese drones are so dominant that South Korea’s production is slipping.

No easy answers:While NATO allies are pushing for new drone co-production agreements, the bottlenecks are a big obstacle. Allies are looking at stockpiling magnets and germanium. But stockpiling doesn’t really break dependence, Tollast said.

Breaking China’s stranglehold, he said, is a “multi-year challenge” that will take investments in mining and magnet production — the kind of effort the Pentagon made this year inbuying a 50 percent stake in California-based rare earth miner MP Materials.

Beijing is learning how to squeeze Taiwan without ever firing a shot. And a new war game shows how little it would take to trigger a global crisis.

Participants said the pressure point is Taiwan’s near-total reliance on imported energy and a heavy dependence on liquefied natural gas.

State of play:A freshseries of tabletop exercisesfrom the hawkish Washington-based think tank Foundation for Defense of Democracies sketches out a slow-motion energy siege that Taiwan is not positioned to withstand. The game showed China can bring Taipei to its knees with lawfare, bureaucratic chokepoints and cyber harassment — tactics the players say Beijing is already employing.

“This is the most likely scenario,” said retired Rear Adm.Mark Montgomery, of the think tank. “It’s the one that we think is going on right now.”

He described a “cyber-enabled economic warfare campaign” using diplomatic, economic and administrative tools, all meant to stay “below the level of response” from the U.S. and Japan.

Even a modest disruption of Taiwan’s liquified natural gas supplies, which make up about half of its power mix, would force a wrenching choice between keeping homes lit and keeping chip fabs running. It’s a decision that would trigger a semiconductor world shock.

“Do I keep it as my problem, or do I make it the world’s problem?” Montgomery said. “And I’m with … any other leader of Taiwan that says I need to make this a world problem.”

U.S. PresidentDonald Trumpought to quit trying “carrots” to get Russian PresidentVladimir Putinto the negotiating table and turn to new sanctions to cripple Russian industry, Finnish leaderAlexander Stubbsaid in an interview. “Right now we’re in stick mode,” said Stubb. “The next step should be sanctions — the sanctions package in the [U.S.] Senate.”

CLARIFICATION:  This newsletter has been updated to clarify the Foundation for Defense of Democracies' foreign policy orientation.

Title: Trump’s toughest trade talks are about to start
Content:
ByCATHERINE KIM

10/29/2025 06:40 PM EDT

Presented by FirstNet, Built with AT&T

President Donald Trump walks with South Korean President Lee Jae Myung after a high honor presentation ceremony at the Gyeongju National Museum in Gyeongju on October 29, 2025.  | Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty Images

DEALS, DEALS, DEALS— In terms of making deals, President Donald Trump’s Asia tour so far looks like a rousing success, with him inking trade agreements with major allies and presiding over a peace pact between Cambodia and Thailand. But the real challenge is still ahead: a bilateral summit with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

In just a few hours, Trump and Xi are scheduled to meet in Gyeongju, South Korea, on the sidelines of this year’s APEC summit, which brings together countries in the Pacific Rim to facilitate open trade.

The meeting with Xi comes at the tail end of afive-day Asia tripthat has helped Trump burnish his reputation as a dealmaker. In Southeast Asia, he’snegotiated new tradeagreements and also secured more access to rare earth and critical minerals in countries like Thailand, Malaysia, Cambodia and Vietnam. During Trump’s visit, Japan similarly pledged toinvest $550 billionin U.S. industry and cooperate in supplying critical minerals. Meanwhile,South Korea has also finalized its trade dealwith Trump: Out of the $350 billion Seoul has pledged to invest in the U.S., it will pay $200 billion in cash in installments, while $150 billion will be used toward investments in the U.S. shipbuilding industry.

Although the actual execution of these trade deals is still in the future, the announcements are enough to help Trump position himself as “someone that can go around the world and make deals that are good for the United States,” said Karl Friedhoff, an East Asia expert at the Chicago Council on Global Affairs.

Don’t expect that same kind of swift dealmaking from the Trump-Xi meeting, though. Both presidents seem dug in, Friedhoff said, and it is unlikely the two will leave the summit landing a deal on anything.

The matters at hand are pressing: Trade tension is high, as both countries have imposed tariffs on each other, with threats to raise them even further next month. The U.S. has said it would consider lowering tariffs if Xi cracks down on the export of chemicals used to produce fentanyl, despite China saying it has done everything it can to address the issue. China may also be able to negotiate lower tariffs if it relaxes its restrictions on the export of rare earths, as the country accounts for most of the global supply.

China, too, is likely to make its own demands. A key issue raised in the past is the U.S.’s restrictions on importing advanced technology like AI chips. China isn’t the only one pushing for a resumption in sales: chipmaker Nvidia has also been lobbying Trump to allow the company to export its advanced chips to China. And although Trump has publicly said he wants to focus on trade during the meeting, Xi may ask the U.S. to pull back its support for Taiwan.

Luckily for the U.S., Trump’s apparent success in sealing deals with other Asian nations during his trip makes him stronger as he heads into these negotiations, said Shay Wester, the director of Asian economic affairs at the Asia Society.

“It shows China that the U.S. is a force to be reckoned with, not because of the concessions on the tariffs — you know that these countries will pay tariffs — it’s because of them willing to really align with the U.S. on a lot of economic security efforts,” he said.

China, too, however, has experienced changes that make it unlikely to be the same nation that signed the Phase One trade pact with Trump in 2020. Since then, Xi has pushed out his rivals andfully cinched power in China. In this new era, he’s flexing his authority and is unwilling to waver in competition against the U.S., especially as the country’sfive-year economic strategyfocuses on building a self-reliant and resilient economy.

And despite Trump’s many wins in Asia over the last few days, there’s a chance he could be outshone by China. Since Trump has decided to skip APEC’s core “Economic Leaders’ Meeting,” which begins the day after he leaves on Thursday, China will be the largest economy in the room.

“The U.S. leadership is just never present enough in Asia, and when they do that, guess who is generally there? It’s China,” Friedhoff said. “They’re ceding leadership.”

Welcome to POLITICO Nightly.Reach out with news, tips and ideas at[email protected]. Or contact tonight’s author at[email protected]or on X (formerly known as Twitter) at@ck_525.

New from POLITICO Canada:ThePlaybook Canadapodcast — Our colleagues Nick Taylor-Vaisey and Mickey Djuric — the plugged-in reporters behind Canada Playbook — are bringing their sharp political insight to a new weekly podcast. Each Thursday morning, they’ll unpack the stories driving the news in Ottawa and beyond — the characters, conflicts and conversations setting the national agenda — plus a fan-favorite feature: their 200-second interviews with the people shaping Canadian politics. The first episode drops Oct. 30. Listen to the trailer and subscribe onApple,Spotifyor wherever you get your podcasts.

A message from FirstNet, Built with AT&T:

— Meet the Senate aide with a $44,000 taxpayer-funded commute:The top aide to Sen. Roger Marshall of Kansascharged $44,000 to taxpayers over the past two years in commuting expensesbetween Washington and Lynchburg, Virginia, where he lives, according to public records. The reimbursements paid to Brent Robertson are legal and comply with congressional rules governing expense reimbursements, according to experts who reviewed his arrangement, but they also said it was highly unusual and at odds with the intent behind those rules. Typically senior congressional aides are stationed either in Washington or their employer’s home state.

— Hegseth to unveil arms sale overhaul:Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth isplanning to unveil a consequential overhaul of U.S. arms salesthat could reshape how the Pentagon sends weapons to allies and help replenish dwindling stockpiles. Hegseth is expected to announce the changes on Nov. 7 at an unusual gathering of defense industry executives, according to seven people familiar with the planning. The effort is a major test for the novice Defense secretary, whom Vice President JD Vance has called an effective “disrupter.”

— DOJ tried to subpoena an online trans health care provider. A judge quashed it:A federal judge hasdealt a fresh blow to the Trump administration’s attempt to crack down on doctorswho provide gender-affirming care to transgender people. U.S. District Judge Jamal Whitehead ruled that a wide-ranging subpoena the Justice Department served in June on QueerDoc, a medical practice offering gender-affirming care online, cannot be enforced because the demand was not part of a legitimate law enforcement investigation.

— Vance dodges ‘premature’ talks of 2028 — but keeps options open:Vancebrushed off murmurs of a 2028 presidential runalongside Secretary of State Marco Rubio, as the early jockeying to succeed President Donald Trump as head of the Republican Party gets underway. In a podcast interview with the New York Post’s “Pod Force One” released Wednesday, Vance dismissed the idea of a presidential bid as “premature” but suggested he’d be open to the plan later in his term.

— ICE quietly furloughed its congressional relations team during shutdown:Immigration and Customs Enforcement hasquietly furloughed most of its congressional relations teamamid the government shutdown, a group of House Democrats alleged in a letter sent to acting ICE chief Todd Lyons on Wednesday. The 15 House Democrats said they now have no clear point of contact to obtain details about detainees and why they have been placed in ICE custody, or information about conditions in detention facilities.

— ICE shake-up will increase arrest numbers. That doesn’t mean there will be more deportations:The Trump administration’sleadership shake-up at Immigration and Customs Enforcementis likely to boost arrest numbers and fuel its aggressive messaging campaign, but will have little effect on President Donald Trump’s broader goal of rapidly deporting more immigrants, according to five people, including Trump administration officials, people close to the administration and former ICE officials.

TROOPS WITHDRAW— The United States has begundownsizing its military presence in Europe, Romania’s defense ministry confirmed Wednesday.

The Romanian ministry said in a statement that Bucharest and other allies “have been informed about the United States’ decision to downsize American troops in Europe,” describing it as part of a broader reassessment of U.S. global force posture.

ACCESS BLOCKED— The European Parliament isconsidering whether to ban access to Russian websitessuch as Sputnik and RT from its IT infrastructure.

Scores of websites hosting the broadcasters’ content remain accessible despite the EU sanctioning Russian media across the bloc in 2022 after Moscow launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine.

The right-wing European Conservatives and Reformists, whose Polish and Italian leaders publicly oppose Russia’s war, asked during a political group leaders’ meeting on Oct. 15 for “Russian propaganda websites under EU sanctions” to be made inaccessible on Parliament’s IT infrastructure.

CONSENT CONSIDERED— French lawmakers approved legislation Wednesday thatintroduced the concept of consent in the legal definition of rapefollowing the shocking Gisèle Pelicot trial last year.

While advocates have been pushing for years for France to change the definition of rape and sexual assault to outlaw nonconsensual acts, Pelicot’s case, where 51 men were accused of raping her with the help of her now ex-husband, who had drugged her, gave new impetus to the campaign.

HOT TO GO— Nowadays, you can order anything to your doorstep: groceries, appliances, an ice cream sundae, a martini, an expertly seared Wagyu steak. But take-out is rapidly killing the restaurant industry, or at least drastically shaping it into something anew: less of a physical space to sit and dine, and more of a glorified takeout counter. Last year, nearly 75 percent of restaurant orders weren’t eaten in the restaurant itself. For The Atlantic, Ellen Cushing reports on how the restaurant industry turned into a mere army ferrying“hot food out of professional kitchens and into American mouths.”

More than 1,000 demonstrators, accompanied by a brass band playing circus music, tried in vain to close the Stock Exchange on the 50th anniversary of the 1929 stock market crash. | David Karp/AP
